frameDefinitions: This frame contains words for motions or actions an Agent performs using some part of his/her body.
An Agent, by virtue of strength or forcefulness, controls, rules, or strongly influences some Patient in some Situation.
In this frame an Ingestor takes a Substance into his or her body.
This frame deals with a Healer treating and curing an Affliction (the injuries, disease, or pain) of the Patient, sometimes also mentioning the use of a particular Treatment or Medication.
The words in this frame describe the manipulation of an Entity by an Agent.
The words in this frame describe situations in which an Agent or a Cause injures a Victim.
frameExamples: The fireballing righthander looked poised to <t>dominate</t> the Yankees yet again, striking out seven straight batters during one stretch
You should refrain from <t>taking</t> vodka up the nose.
Isis then <t>cured</t> Re by reciting a spell.
Rod saw his father <t>beating</t> his mother.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Agent</fen> uses some part of his/her body to perform the action. <fen>Agent</fen> occurs as the External Argument.
With some verbs in this frame, the <fen>Body_part</fen> involved in the action is specified by the meaning of the verb and cannot be expressed separately.  For example,
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the body movement occurs.
The location within which the movement of a <fen>Body_part</fen> takes place.
The <fen>Agent</fen> controls the Patient by being forceful and possibly aggressive.
The <fen>Patient</fen> is trying to gain control of a situation, but ends up being subject to the control and influence of the <fen>Agent</fen>.
The time when the domination takes place.
The place where the domination occurs.
The <fen>Delivery_device</fen> is the means by which the <fen>Substance</fen> is ingested.
The <fen>Ingestor</fen> ingests the <fen>Substance</fen>.
The <fen>Substance</fen> is the drug or other substance that is ingested by the <fen>Ingestor</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Ingestor</fen> ingests the <fen>Substance</fen>.
The <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Ingestor</fen> ingests the <fen>Substance</fen>.
The  Healer, anyone who treats or cures the Patient, occurs as the External Argument of verbs:

This   is the sufferer of the injury, disease or pain and can occur as an NP Object in this frame. However, Patient may not be expressed as a separate Frame Element but frequently occurs as the possessor of the Affliction, an example of  role Conflation:  (See section on Conflation.)
The Frame Element Affliction is generally the NP Object of a verb, frequently incorporating the Patient as a possessor, as described above:
The role Treatment is used for treatments and means, distinguished by separate FEs in FN-1.
The injested, applied, injected, etc. substance designed to cure the Patient.
The <fen>Body_part</fen> is the specific area of the <fen>Patient</fen>'s body which is treated.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.

The <fen>Agent</fen> manipulates an object. <fen>Agent</fen> typically refers to animate beings, but is also extended to mechanical and other inanimate objects.  <fen>Agent</fen> is most frequently expressed as the external argument of verbs:
The <fen>Entity</fen> being manipulated often occurs as the direct object of verbs:

The part of the <fen>Agent</fen>'s body being used to manipulate the <fen>Entity</fen> may also be expressed. While the default is for an <fen>Agent</fen> to use his/her hands, other body parts may be specified. This frame element usually occurs as a PP-complement.
When the manipulation takes place
The spatial setting in which the manipulation takes place.
<fen>Agent</fen> is the person causing the <fen>Victim</fen>'s injury.

The <fen>Victim</fen> is the being or entity that is injured.  If the <fen>Victim</fen> is included in the phrase indicating <fen>Body_part</fen>, the <fen>Victim</fen> role is tagged on a second role layer (see 3rd example).
The <fen>Body_part</fen> identifies the location on the body where the bodily injury takes place.
The <fen>Cause</fen> marks expressions that indicate some non-intentional, typically non-human, force that inflicts harm on the <fen>Victim</fen>
<fen>Time</fen> identifies the time when the harm-causing event occurs.
<fen>Place</fen> identifies the place where the harm causing event occurs.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The boy</fex> swung his legs.
Pat yawned (*his mouth).
There was singing for joy in the streets, and <fex>everywhere</fex> people lifting their arms into the air.
Their role models might have dominated women <fex>in the past</fex>; they may not have understood the concept of equality.
Women tend to dominatemen <fex>at home and at Church</fex>.
Tabitha smoked <fex>a pipe</fex>.
<fex>Doctors</fex> alleviated his suffering.
Acupuncture cured <fex>Pat</fex> of his depression.
This potion heals <fex>a broken heart</fex>.
He emphasized treatment <fex>by surgical means</fex>.
He needs prolonged treatment <fex>with anibiotics</fex>.
<fex>A robot arm</fex> grasps the box on the conveyor belt and seals it.
Squeeze <fex>the ball</fex> as many times as you can.
Kim grasped the needle <fex>between finger and thumb</fex>.
I seized the letter <fex>before he did</fex>.
<fex>In the hallway</fex> he managed to grabthe monarch by the ankles
<fex>Jolosa, who</fex> broke a rival player 's jaw, was told to model his play on the England striker.
Someone bashed <fex>him</fex> on the back of the head with a heavy smooth object.
Someone bashed him <fex>on the back of the head</fex> with a heavy smooth object.
<fex>A falling rock</fex> crushed my ankle.
Riot police in Nairobi clubbed four women unconscious <fex>on March 3</fex>.
Boys  are punched <fex>at school</fex> for payback
